description: From Late Latin tautologia, from Ancient Greek ταὐτολογία (tautología) from ταὐτός (tautós, “the same”) + λόγος (lógos, “explanation”), analyzed as tauto- +‎ -logy.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Redundant use of words, a pleonasm, an unnecessary and tedious repetition.
examples: It is tautology to say, "Forward Planning".
The expression "raze to the ground" is a tautology, since the word "raze" includes the notion "to the ground".

entries.meaning: (countable, logic, propositional logic) A statement that is true for all truth values of its propositional variables.
(countable, logic, first-order logic) A statement that is true for all truth values of its Boolean atoms.
